Comment: This command info is generated from fig
Name: pnpm
Description: Fast, disk space efficient package manager

Arguments.Name: -C
Arguments.Description: Run as if pnpm was started in <path> instead of the current working directory

Arguments.Name: path
Arguments.Description: path

Arguments.Name: -w
Arguments.Description: Run as if pnpm was started in the root of the <workspace> instead of the current working directory

Arguments.Name: workspace
Arguments.Description: workspace

Arguments.Name: -h
Arguments.Description: Output usage information

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Show pnpm's version

Arguments.Name: Scripts
Arguments.Description: Scripts

Arguments.Name: add
Arguments.Description: Installs a package and any packages that it depends on. By default, any new package is installed as a production dependency

Arguments.Name: --offline
Arguments.Description: If true, pnpm will use only packages already available in the store. If a package won't be found locally, the installation will fail

Arguments.Name: --prefer-offline
Arguments.Description: If true, staleness checks for cached data will be bypassed, but missing data will be requested from the server. To force full offline mode, use --offline

Arguments.Name: --ignore-scripts
Arguments.Description: Do not execute any scripts defined in the project package.json and its dependencies

Arguments.Name: --reporter
Arguments.Description: Allows you to choose the reporter that will log debug info to the terminal about the installation progress

Arguments.Name: Reporter Type
Arguments.Description: Reporter Type

Arguments.Name: silent
Arguments.Description: Reporter Type

Arguments.Name: default
Arguments.Description: Reporter Type

Arguments.Name: append-only
Arguments.Description: Reporter Type

Arguments.Name: ndjson
Arguments.Description: Reporter Type

Arguments.Name: -P
Arguments.Description: Install the specified packages as regular dependencies

Arguments.Name: -D
Arguments.Description: Install the specified packages as devDependencies

Arguments.Name: -O
Arguments.Description: Install the specified packages as optionalDependencies

Arguments.Name: --no-save
Arguments.Description: Prevents saving to `dependencies`

Arguments.Name: -E
Arguments.Description: Saved dependencies will be configured with an exact version rather than using pnpm's default semver range operator

Arguments.Name: --save-peer
Arguments.Description: Using --save-peer will add one or more packages to peerDependencies and install them as dev dependencies

Arguments.Name: --ignore-workspace-root-check
Arguments.Description:
Adding a new dependency to the root workspace package fails, unless the --ignore-workspace-root-check or -W flag is used.
For instance, pnpm add debug -W

Arguments.Name: --global
Arguments.Description: Install a package globally

Arguments.Name: --workspace
Arguments.Description: Only adds the new dependency if it is found in the workspace

Arguments.Name: --filter
Arguments.Description:
Filtering allows you to restrict commands to specific subsets of packages.
pnpm supports a rich selector syntax for picking packages by name or by relation.
More details: https://pnpm.io/filtering

Arguments.Name: Filepath / Package
Arguments.Description: Filepath / Package

Arguments.Name: package
Arguments.Description: package

Arguments.Name: install
Arguments.Description:
Pnpm install is used to install all dependencies for a project.
In a CI environment, installation fails if a lockfile is present but needs an update.
Inside a workspace, pnpm install installs all dependencies in all the projects.
If you want to disable this behavior, set the recursive-install setting to false

Arguments.Name: package
Arguments.Description: package

Arguments.Name: install-test
Arguments.Description: Runs pnpm install followed immediately by pnpm test. It takes exactly the same arguments as pnpm install

Arguments.Name: --offline
Arguments.Description: If true, pnpm will use only packages already available in the store. If a package won't be found locally, the installation will fail

Arguments.Name: --prefer-offline
Arguments.Description: If true, staleness checks for cached data will be bypassed, but missing data will be requested from the server. To force full offline mode, use --offline

Arguments.Name: --ignore-scripts
Arguments.Description: Do not execute any scripts defined in the project package.json and its dependencies

Arguments.Name: --reporter
Arguments.Description: Allows you to choose the reporter that will log debug info to the terminal about the installation progress

Arguments.Name: Reporter Type
Arguments.Description: Reporter Type

Arguments.Name: silent
Arguments.Description: Reporter Type

Arguments.Name: default
Arguments.Description: Reporter Type

Arguments.Name: append-only
Arguments.Description: Reporter Type

Arguments.Name: ndjson
Arguments.Description: Reporter Type

Arguments.Name: -P
Arguments.Description:
Pnpm will not install any package listed in devDependencies if the NODE_ENV environment variable is set to production.
Use this flag to instruct pnpm to ignore NODE_ENV and take its production status from this flag instead

Arguments.Name: -D
Arguments.Description: Only devDependencies are installed regardless of the NODE_ENV

Arguments.Name: --no-optional
Arguments.Description: OptionalDependencies are not installed

Arguments.Name: --lockfile-only
Arguments.Description: When used, only updates pnpm-lock.yaml and package.json instead of checking node_modules and downloading dependencies

Arguments.Name: --frozen-lockfile
Arguments.Description: If true, pnpm doesn't generate a lockfile and fails to install if the lockfile is out of sync with the manifest / an update is needed or no lockfile is present

Arguments.Name: --use-store-server
Arguments.Description: Starts a store server in the background. The store server will keep running after installation is done. To stop the store server, run pnpm server stop

Arguments.Name: --shamefully-hoist
Arguments.Description: Creates a flat node_modules structure, similar to that of npm or yarn. WARNING: This is highly discouraged

Arguments.Name: update
Arguments.Description:
Pnpm update updates packages to their latest version based on the specified range.
When used without arguments, updates all dependencies. You can use patterns to update specific dependencies

Arguments.Name: --recursive
Arguments.Description: Concurrently runs update in all subdirectories with a package.json (excluding node_modules)

Arguments.Name: --latest
Arguments.Description: Ignores the version range specified in package.json. Instead, the version specified by the latest tag will be used (potentially upgrading the packages across major versions)

Arguments.Name: --global
Arguments.Description: Update global packages

Arguments.Name: -P
Arguments.Description: Only update packages in dependencies and optionalDependencies

Arguments.Name: -D
Arguments.Description: Only update packages in devDependencies

Arguments.Name: --no-optional
Arguments.Description: Don't update packages in optionalDependencies

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Show outdated dependencies and select which ones to update

Arguments.Name: --workspace
Arguments.Description:
Tries to link all packages from the workspace. Versions are updated to match the versions of packages inside the workspace.
If specific packages are updated, the command will fail if any of the updated dependencies are not found inside the workspace. For instance, the following command fails if express is not a workspace package: pnpm up -r --workspace express

Arguments.Name: --filter
Arguments.Description:
Filtering allows you to restrict commands to specific subsets of packages.
pnpm supports a rich selector syntax for picking packages by name or by relation.
More details: https://pnpm.io/filtering

Arguments.Name: Filepath / Package
Arguments.Description: Filepath / Package

Arguments.Name: Package
Arguments.Description: Package

Arguments.Name: remove
Arguments.Description: Removes packages from node_modules and from the project's package.json

Arguments.Name: --recursive
Arguments.Description:
When used inside a workspace, removes a dependency (or dependencies) from every workspace package.
When used not inside a workspace, removes a dependency (or dependencies) from every package found in subdirectories

Arguments.Name: --global
Arguments.Description: Remove a global package

Arguments.Name: -P
Arguments.Description: Only remove the dependency from dependencies

Arguments.Name: -D
Arguments.Description: Only remove the dependency from devDependencies

Arguments.Name: --save-optional
Arguments.Description: Only remove the dependency from optionalDependencies

Arguments.Name: --filter
Arguments.Description:
Filtering allows you to restrict commands to specific subsets of packages.
pnpm supports a rich selector syntax for picking packages by name or by relation.
More details: https://pnpm.io/filtering

Arguments.Name: Filepath / Package
Arguments.Description: Filepath / Package

Arguments.Name: Package
Arguments.Description: Package

Arguments.Name: link
Arguments.Description: Makes the current local package accessible system-wide, or in another location

Arguments.Name: --dir
Arguments.Description: Changes the link location to <dir>

Arguments.Name: --global
Arguments.Description: Links the specified package (<pkg>) from global node_modules to the node_nodules of package from where this command was executed or specified via --dir option

Arguments.Name: Package
Arguments.Description: Package

Arguments.Name: unlink
Arguments.Description:
Unlinks a system-wide package (inverse of pnpm link).
If called without arguments, all linked dependencies will be unlinked.
This is similar to yarn unlink, except pnpm re-installs the dependency after removing the external link

Arguments.Name: --recursive
Arguments.Description: Unlink in every package found in subdirectories or in every workspace package, when executed inside a workspace

Arguments.Name: --filter
Arguments.Description:
Filtering allows you to restrict commands to specific subsets of packages.
pnpm supports a rich selector syntax for picking packages by name or by relation.
More details: https://pnpm.io/filtering

Arguments.Name: Filepath / Package
Arguments.Description: Filepath / Package

Arguments.Name: Package
Arguments.Description: Package

Arguments.Name: import
Arguments.Description: Pnpm import generates a pnpm-lock.yaml from an npm package-lock.json (or npm-shrinkwrap.json) file

Arguments.Name: rebuild
Arguments.Description: Rebuild a package

Arguments.Name: --recursive
Arguments.Description: This command runs the pnpm rebuild command in every package of the monorepo

Arguments.Name: --filter
Arguments.Description:
Filtering allows you to restrict commands to specific subsets of packages.
pnpm supports a rich selector syntax for picking packages by name or by relation.
More details: https://pnpm.io/filtering

Arguments.Name: Filepath / Package
Arguments.Description: Filepath / Package

Arguments.Name: Package
Arguments.Description: Package

Arguments.Name: prune
Arguments.Description: Removes unnecessary packages

Arguments.Name: --prod
Arguments.Description: Remove the packages specified in devDependencies

Arguments.Name: --no-optional
Arguments.Description: Remove the packages specified in optionalDependencies

Arguments.Name: fetch
Arguments.Description: EXPERIMENTAL FEATURE: Fetch packages from a lockfile into virtual store, package manifest is ignored: https://pnpm.io/cli/fetch

Arguments.Name: --prod
Arguments.Description: Development packages will not be fetched

Arguments.Name: --dev
Arguments.Description: Only development packages will be fetched

Arguments.Name: patch
Arguments.Description: This command will cause a package to be extracted in a temporary directory intended to be editable at will

Arguments.Name: --edit-dir
Arguments.Description: The package that needs to be patched will be extracted to this directory

Arguments.Name: package
Arguments.Description: package

Arguments.Name: patch-commit
Arguments.Description: Generate a patch out of a directory

Arguments.Name: dir
Arguments.Description: dir

Arguments.Name: package
Arguments.Description: package

Arguments.Name: audit
Arguments.Description:
Checks for known security issues with the installed packages.
If security issues are found, try to update your dependencies via pnpm update.
If a simple update does not fix all the issues, use overrides to force versions that are not vulnerable.
For instance, if lodash@<2.1.0 is vulnerable, use overrides to force lodash@^2.1.0.
Details at: https://pnpm.io/cli/audit

Arguments.Name: --audit-level
Arguments.Description: Only print advisories with severity greater than or equal to <severity>

Arguments.Name: Audit Level
Arguments.Description: Audit Level

Arguments.Name: low
Arguments.Description: Audit Level

Arguments.Name: moderate
Arguments.Description: Audit Level

Arguments.Name: high
Arguments.Description: Audit Level

Arguments.Name: critical
Arguments.Description: Audit Level

Arguments.Name: --fix
Arguments.Description: Add overrides to the package.json file in order to force non-vulnerable versions of the dependencies

Arguments.Name: --json
Arguments.Description: Output audit report in JSON format

Arguments.Name: --dev
Arguments.Description: Only audit dev dependencies

Arguments.Name: --prod
Arguments.Description: Only audit production dependencies

Arguments.Name: --no-optional
Arguments.Description: Don't audit optionalDependencies

Arguments.Name: --ignore-registry-errors
Arguments.Description: If the registry responds with a non-200 status code, the process should exit with 0. So the process will fail only if the registry actually successfully responds with found vulnerabilities

Arguments.Name: list
Arguments.Description:
This command will output all the versions of packages that are installed, as well as their dependencies, in a tree-structure.
Positional arguments are name-pattern@version-range identifiers, which will limit the results to only the packages named. For example, pnpm list "babel-*" "eslint-*" semver@5

Arguments.Name: --recursive
Arguments.Description: Perform command on every package in subdirectories or on every workspace package, when executed inside a workspace

Arguments.Name: --json
Arguments.Description: Log output in JSON format

Arguments.Name: --long
Arguments.Description: Show extended information

Arguments.Name: --parseable
Arguments.Description: Outputs package directories in a parseable format instead of their tree view

Arguments.Name: --global
Arguments.Description: List packages in the global install directory instead of in the current project

Arguments.Name: --depth
Arguments.Description:
Max display depth of the dependency tree.
pnpm ls --depth 0 will list direct dependencies only. pnpm ls --depth -1 will list projects only. Useful inside a workspace when used with the -r option

Arguments.Name: number
Arguments.Description: number

Arguments.Name: --dev
Arguments.Description: Only list dev dependencies

Arguments.Name: --prod
Arguments.Description: Only list production dependencies

Arguments.Name: --no-optional
Arguments.Description: Don't list optionalDependencies

Arguments.Name: --filter
Arguments.Description:
Filtering allows you to restrict commands to specific subsets of packages.
pnpm supports a rich selector syntax for picking packages by name or by relation.
More details: https://pnpm.io/filtering

Arguments.Name: Filepath / Package
Arguments.Description: Filepath / Package

Arguments.Name: outdated
Arguments.Description: Checks for outdated packages. The check can be limited to a subset of the installed packages by providing arguments (patterns are supported)

Arguments.Name: --recursive
Arguments.Description: Check for outdated dependencies in every package found in subdirectories, or in every workspace package when executed inside a workspace

Arguments.Name: --long
Arguments.Description: Print details

Arguments.Name: --global
Arguments.Description: List outdated global packages

Arguments.Name: --no-table
Arguments.Description: Prints the outdated dependencies in a list format instead of the default table. Good for small consoles

Arguments.Name: --compatible
Arguments.Description: Prints only versions that satisfy specifications in package.json

Arguments.Name: --dev
Arguments.Description: Only list dev dependencies

Arguments.Name: --prod
Arguments.Description: Only list production dependencies

Arguments.Name: --no-optional
Arguments.Description: Doesn't check optionalDependencies

Arguments.Name: why
Arguments.Description: Shows all packages that depend on the specified package

Arguments.Name: --recursive
Arguments.Description: Show the dependency tree for the specified package on every package in subdirectories or on every workspace package when executed inside a workspace

Arguments.Name: --json
Arguments.Description: Log output in JSON format

Arguments.Name: --long
Arguments.Description: Show verbose output

Arguments.Name: --parseable
Arguments.Description: Show parseable output instead of tree view

Arguments.Name: --global
Arguments.Description: List packages in the global install directory instead of in the current project

Arguments.Name: --dev
Arguments.Description: Only display the dependency tree for packages in devDependencies

Arguments.Name: --prod
Arguments.Description: Only display the dependency tree for packages in dependencies

Arguments.Name: --filter
Arguments.Description:
Filtering allows you to restrict commands to specific subsets of packages.
pnpm supports a rich selector syntax for picking packages by name or by relation.
More details: https://pnpm.io/filtering

Arguments.Name: Filepath / Package
Arguments.Description: Filepath / Package

Arguments.Name: Scripts
Arguments.Description: Scripts

Arguments.Name: run
Arguments.Description: Runs a script defined in the package's manifest file

Arguments.Name: -r
Arguments.Description: This runs an arbitrary command from each package's "scripts" object. If a package doesn't have the command, it is skipped. If none of the packages have the command, the command fails

Arguments.Name: --if-present
Arguments.Description: You can use the --if-present flag to avoid exiting with a non-zero exit code when the script is undefined. This lets you run potentially undefined scripts without breaking the execution chain

Arguments.Name: --parallel
Arguments.Description: Completely disregard concurrency and topological sorting, running a given script immediately in all matching packages with prefixed streaming output. This is the preferred flag for long-running processes over many packages, for instance, a lengthy build process

Arguments.Name: --stream
Arguments.Description: Stream output from child processes immediately, prefixed with the originating package directory. This allows output from different packages to be interleaved

Arguments.Name: --filter
Arguments.Description:
Filtering allows you to restrict commands to specific subsets of packages.
pnpm supports a rich selector syntax for picking packages by name or by relation.
More details: https://pnpm.io/filtering

Arguments.Name: Filepath / Package
Arguments.Description: Filepath / Package

Arguments.Name: Scripts
Arguments.Description: Scripts

Arguments.Name: exec
Arguments.Description:
Execute a shell command in scope of a project.
node_modules/.bin is added to the PATH, so pnpm exec allows executing commands of dependencies

Arguments.Name: -r
Arguments.Description:
Execute the shell command in every project of the workspace.
The name of the current package is available through the environment variable PNPM_PACKAGE_NAME (supported from pnpm v2.22.0 onwards)

Arguments.Name: --parallel
Arguments.Description: Completely disregard concurrency and topological sorting, running a given script immediately in all matching packages with prefixed streaming output. This is the preferred flag for long-running processes over many packages, for instance, a lengthy build process

Arguments.Name: --filter
Arguments.Description:
Filtering allows you to restrict commands to specific subsets of packages.
pnpm supports a rich selector syntax for picking packages by name or by relation.
More details: https://pnpm.io/filtering

Arguments.Name: Filepath / Package
Arguments.Description: Filepath / Package

Arguments.Name: Scripts
Arguments.Description: Scripts

Arguments.Name: test
Arguments.Description:
Runs an arbitrary command specified in the package's test property of its scripts object.
The intended usage of the property is to specify a command that runs unit or integration testing for your program

Arguments.Name: start
Arguments.Description:
Runs an arbitrary command specified in the package's start property of its scripts object. If no start property is specified on the scripts object, it will attempt to run node server.js as a default, failing if neither are present.
The intended usage of the property is to specify a command that starts your program

Arguments.Name: publish
Arguments.Description:
Publishes a package to the registry.
When publishing a package inside a workspace, the LICENSE file from the root of the workspace is packed with the package (unless the package has a license of its own).
You may override some fields before publish, using the publishConfig field in package.json. You also can use the publishConfig.directory to customize the published subdirectory (usually using third party build tools).
When running this command recursively (pnpm -r publish), pnpm will publish all the packages that have versions not yet published to the registry

Arguments.Name: --tag
Arguments.Description: Publishes the package with the given tag. By default, pnpm publish updates the latest tag

Arguments.Name: <tag>
Arguments.Description: <tag>

Arguments.Name: --dry-run
Arguments.Description: Does everything a publish would do except actually publishing to the registry

Arguments.Name: --ignore-scripts
Arguments.Description: Ignores any publish related lifecycle scripts (prepublishOnly, postpublish, and the like)

Arguments.Name: --no-git-checks
Arguments.Description: Don't check if current branch is your publish branch, clean, and up-to-date

Arguments.Name: --access
Arguments.Description: Tells the registry whether the published package should be public or restricted

Arguments.Name: Type
Arguments.Description: Type

Arguments.Name: public
Arguments.Description: Type

Arguments.Name: private
Arguments.Description: Type

Arguments.Name: --force
Arguments.Description: Try to publish packages even if their current version is already found in the registry

Arguments.Name: --report-summary
Arguments.Description: Save the list of published packages to pnpm-publish-summary.json. Useful when some other tooling is used to report the list of published packages

Arguments.Name: --filter
Arguments.Description:
Filtering allows you to restrict commands to specific subsets of packages.
pnpm supports a rich selector syntax for picking packages by name or by relation.
More details: https://pnpm.io/filtering

Arguments.Name: Filepath / Package
Arguments.Description: Filepath / Package

Arguments.Name: Branch
Arguments.Description: Branch

Arguments.Name: recursive
Arguments.Description: Runs a pnpm command recursively on all subdirectories in the package or every available workspace

Arguments.Name: --link-workspace-packages
Arguments.Description:
Link locally available packages in workspaces of a monorepo into node_modules instead of re-downloading them from the registry. This emulates functionality similar to yarn workspaces.
When this is set to deep, local packages can also be linked to subdependencies.
Be advised that it is encouraged instead to use npmrc for this setting, to enforce the same behaviour in all environments. This option exists solely so you may override that if necessary

Arguments.Name: bool or `deep`
Arguments.Description: bool or `deep`

Arguments.Name: dee[
Arguments.Description: bool or `deep`

Arguments.Name: --workspace-concurrency
Arguments.Description: Set the maximum number of tasks to run simultaneously. For unlimited concurrency use Infinity

Arguments.Name: <number>
Arguments.Description: <number>

Arguments.Name: --bail
Arguments.Description: Stops when a task throws an error

Arguments.Name: --no-bail
Arguments.Description: Don't stop when a task throws an error

Arguments.Name: --sort
Arguments.Description: Packages are sorted topologically (dependencies before dependents)

Arguments.Name: --no-sort
Arguments.Description: Disable packages sorting

Arguments.Name: --reverse
Arguments.Description: The order of packages is reversed

Arguments.Description: Checks for outdated packages. The check can be limited to a subset of the installed packages by providing arguments (patterns are supported)

Arguments.Name: --recursive
Arguments.Description: Check for outdated dependencies in every package found in subdirectories, or in every workspace package when executed inside a workspace

Arguments.Name: --long
Arguments.Description: Print details

Arguments.Name: --global
Arguments.Description: List outdated global packages

Arguments.Name: --no-table
Arguments.Description: Prints the outdated dependencies in a list format instead of the default table. Good for small consoles

Arguments.Name: --compatible
Arguments.Description: Prints only versions that satisfy specifications in package.json

Arguments.Name: --dev
Arguments.Description: Only list dev dependencies

Arguments.Name: --prod
Arguments.Description: Only list production dependencies

Arguments.Name: --no-optional
Arguments.Description: Doesn't check optionalDependencies

Arguments.Name: why
Arguments.Description: Shows all packages that depend on the specified package

Arguments.Name: --recursive
Arguments.Description: Show the dependency tree for the specified package on every package in subdirectories or on every workspace package when executed inside a workspace

Arguments.Name: --json
Arguments.Description: Log output in JSON format

Arguments.Name: --long
Arguments.Description: Show verbose output

Arguments.Name: --parseable
Arguments.Description: Show parseable output instead of tree view

Arguments.Name: --global
Arguments.Description: List packages in the global install directory instead of in the current project

Arguments.Name: --dev
Arguments.Description: Only display the dependency tree for packages in devDependencies

Arguments.Name: --prod
Arguments.Description: Only display the dependency tree for packages in dependencies

Arguments.Name: --filter
Arguments.Description:
Filtering allows you to restrict commands to specific subsets of packages.
pnpm supports a rich selector syntax for picking packages by name or by relation.
More details: https://pnpm.io/filtering

Arguments.Name: Filepath / Package
Arguments.Description: Filepath / Package

Arguments.Name: Scripts
Arguments.Description: Scripts

Arguments.Name: run
Arguments.Description: Runs a script defined in the package's manifest file

Arguments.Name: -r
Arguments.Description: This runs an arbitrary command from each package's "scripts" object. If a package doesn't have the command, it is skipped. If none of the packages have the command, the command fails

Arguments.Name: --if-present
Arguments.Description: You can use the --if-present flag to avoid exiting with a non-zero exit code when the script is undefined. This lets you run potentially undefined scripts without breaking the execution chain

Arguments.Name: --parallel
Arguments.Description: Completely disregard concurrency and topological sorting, running a given script immediately in all matching packages with prefixed streaming output. This is the preferred flag for long-running processes over many packages, for instance, a lengthy build process

Arguments.Name: --stream
Arguments.Description: Stream output from child processes immediately, prefixed with the originating package directory. This allows output from different packages to be interleaved

Arguments.Name: --filter
Arguments.Description:
Filtering allows you to restrict commands to specific subsets of packages.
pnpm supports a rich selector syntax for picking packages by name or by relation.
More details: https://pnpm.io/filtering

Arguments.Name: Filepath / Package
Arguments.Description: Filepath / Package

Arguments.Name: Scripts
Arguments.Description: Scripts

Arguments.Name: exec
Arguments.Description:
Execute a shell command in scope of a project.
node_modules/.bin is added to the PATH, so pnpm exec allows executing commands of dependencies

Arguments.Name: -r
Arguments.Description:
Execute the shell command in every project of the workspace.
The name of the current package is available through the environment variable PNPM_PACKAGE_NAME (supported from pnpm v2.22.0 onwards)

Arguments.Name: --parallel
Arguments.Description: Completely disregard concurrency and topological sorting, running a given script immediately in all matching packages with prefixed streaming output. This is the preferred flag for long-running processes over many packages, for instance, a lengthy build process

Arguments.Name: --filter
Arguments.Description:
Filtering allows you to restrict commands to specific subsets of packages.
pnpm supports a rich selector syntax for picking packages by name or by relation.
More details: https://pnpm.io/filtering

Arguments.Name: Filepath / Package
Arguments.Description: Filepath / Package

Arguments.Name: Scripts
Arguments.Description: Scripts

Arguments.Name: test
Arguments.Description:
Runs an arbitrary command specified in the package's test property of its scripts object.
The intended usage of the property is to specify a command that runs unit or integration testing for your program

Arguments.Name: publish
Arguments.Description:
Publishes a package to the registry.
When publishing a package inside a workspace, the LICENSE file from the root of the workspace is packed with the package (unless the package has a license of its own).
You may override some fields before publish, using the publishConfig field in package.json. You also can use the publishConfig.directory to customize the published subdirectory (usually using third party build tools).
When running this command recursively (pnpm -r publish), pnpm will publish all the packages that have versions not yet published to the registry

Arguments.Name: --tag
Arguments.Description: Publishes the package with the given tag. By default, pnpm publish updates the latest tag

Arguments.Name: <tag>
Arguments.Description: <tag>

Arguments.Name: --dry-run
Arguments.Description: Does everything a publish would do except actually publishing to the registry

Arguments.Name: --ignore-scripts
Arguments.Description: Ignores any publish related lifecycle scripts (prepublishOnly, postpublish, and the like)

Arguments.Name: --no-git-checks
Arguments.Description: Don't check if current branch is your publish branch, clean, and up-to-date

Arguments.Name: --access
Arguments.Description: Tells the registry whether the published package should be public or restricted

Arguments.Name: Type
Arguments.Description: Type

Arguments.Name: public
Arguments.Description: Type

Arguments.Name: private
Arguments.Description: Type

Arguments.Name: --force
Arguments.Description: Try to publish packages even if their current version is already found in the registry

Arguments.Name: --report-summary
Arguments.Description: Save the list of published packages to pnpm-publish-summary.json. Useful when some other tooling is used to report the list of published packages

Arguments.Name: --filter
Arguments.Description:
Filtering allows you to restrict commands to specific subsets of packages.
pnpm supports a rich selector syntax for picking packages by name or by relation.
More details: https://pnpm.io/filtering

Arguments.Name: Filepath / Package
Arguments.Description: Filepath / Package

Arguments.Name: Branch
Arguments.Description: Branch

Arguments.Name: server
Arguments.Description: Manage a store server

Arguments.Name: start
Arguments.Description: Starts a server that performs all interactions with the store. Other commands will delegate any store-related tasks to this server

Arguments.Name: --background
Arguments.Description: Runs the server in the background, similar to daemonizing on UNIX systems

Arguments.Name: --network-concurrency
Arguments.Description: The maximum number of network requests to process simultaneously

Arguments.Name: number
Arguments.Description: number

Arguments.Name: --protocol
Arguments.Description: The communication protocol used by the server. When this is set to auto, IPC is used on all systems except for Windows, which uses TCP

Arguments.Name: Type
Arguments.Description: Type

Arguments.Name: auto
Arguments.Description: Type

Arguments.Name: tcp
Arguments.Description: Type

Arguments.Name: ipc
Arguments.Description: Type

Arguments.Name: --port
Arguments.Description: The port number to use when TCP is used for communication. If a port is specified and the protocol is set to auto, regardless of system type, the protocol is automatically set to use TCP

Arguments.Name: port number
Arguments.Description: port number

Arguments.Name: --store-dir
Arguments.Description: The directory to use for the content addressable store

Arguments.Name: Path
Arguments.Description: Path

Arguments.Name: --lock
Arguments.Description: Set to make the package store immutable to external processes while the server is running or not

Arguments.Name: --no-lock
Arguments.Description: Set to make the package store mutable to external processes while the server is running or not

Arguments.Name: --ignore-stop-requests
Arguments.Description: Prevents you from stopping the server using pnpm server stop

Arguments.Name: --ignore-upload-requests
Arguments.Description: Prevents creating a new side effect cache during install

Arguments.Name: stop
Arguments.Description: Stops the store server

Arguments.Name: status
Arguments.Description: Prints information about the running server

Arguments.Name: store
Arguments.Description: Managing the package store

Arguments.Name: status
Arguments.Description:
Checks for modified packages in the store.
Returns exit code 0 if the content of the package is the same as it was at the time of unpacking

Arguments.Name: add
Arguments.Description:
Functionally equivalent to pnpm add,
except this adds new packages to the store directly without modifying any projects or files outside of the store

Arguments.Name: prune
Arguments.Description:
Removes orphan packages from the store.
Pruning the store will save disk space, however may slow down future installations involving pruned packages.
Ultimately, it is a safe operation, however not recommended if you have orphaned packages from a package you intend to reinstall.
Please read the FAQ for more information on unreferenced packages and best practices.
Please note that this is prohibited when a store server is running

Arguments.Name: path
Arguments.Description: Returns the path to the active store directory

Arguments.Name: init
Arguments.Description: Creates a basic package.json file in the current directory, if it doesn't exist already

Arguments.Name: doctor
Arguments.Description: Checks for known common issues with pnpm configuration

CustomArgumentTemplates.Name: Scripts
CustomArgumentTemplates.Command: bash -c until [[ -f package.json ]] || [[ $PWD = '/' ]]; do cd ..; done; cat package.json
